titleStmt.title: The King in the country. A dramatic piece, in two acts. Acted at the Theatres-Royal, at Richmond and Windsor, 1788
titleStmt.author: Waldron, F. G. (Francis Godolphin), 1744-1818.

publicationStmt.publisher: printed for the editor, and sold at No.62, Great Wild-Street; by Mess. Egerton; Mess. Cox and Phillipson; R. Ryan; H. D. Symonds; and W. Richardson,

notesStmt.note: An adaptation by Francis Waldron of the subplot of Thomas Heywood's 'The first and second partes of King Edward the Fourth'.
Also issued, without the second 'Advertisement" leaf as part of : 'The literary museum', London, 1792.
Reproduction of original from the British Library.

Electronic data. Farmington Hills, Mich. : Thomson Gale, 2003. Page image (PNG). Digitized image of the microfilm version produced in Woodbridge, CT by Research Publications, 1982-2002 (later known as Primary Source Microfilm, an imprint of the Gale Group).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A DRAMATIC PIECE, In TWO ACTS.
Acted at the THEATRES-ROYAL, At RICHMOND and WINDSOR, 1788.

LONDON, Printed for the EDITOR, and Sold at No. 62, Great Wild-Street, near Lincoln's-Inn-Fields; by Meſſ. EGERTON, Whitehall; Meſſ. COX and PHILLIPSON, James-Street, Covent-Garden; R. RYAN, No. 351, Oxford-Street; H. D. SYMONDS, No. 20. Pater-Noſter-Row; and W. RICHARDSON, under the Royal-Exchange. 1789.

p.hi: The following Piece is taken from an underplot in The Firſt Part of King Edward the Fourth, written by Thomas Heywood; the dialogue has been altered a little, to render it fit for modern repreſentation; and a few paſſages have been added for connexion and concluſion.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: The Dramatic Piece of "The King in the Country," was compiled and performed laſt ſummer, immediately on His Majeſty's return from Cheltenham; when Entertainments of various kinds were exhibited at the different Places of Public Amuſement, having relation to the Royal Excurſion. The Calamity which, to the grief of every good mind, has ſince befallen Our Beloved Sovereign, does not, it is preſumed, render the publication of this Drama improper; had the Editor thought it ſo, it would certainly have been withheld: for, having been honoured with The Royal Authority to ſuperintend Theatrical Entertainments theſe ten years paſt (during which period it has been neceſſary for him to adapt pieces of a local, or temporary nature, to Provincial Theatres), no one can entertain a more proper ſenſe of duty, reſpect, loyalty, and affection, to Our moſt gracious King, whom God preſerve and reſtore!

div.head: Written on the Bank of the Thames, oppoſite KEW, December 29, 1788.
div.l: By Winter's chilling breath now Silver Thames
Is ice-bound, and his gently-gliding ſtream,
That late convey'd each product of the land
To all who wanted, ſtill diffuſing good,
In torpid ſtupor lies! But oh! worſe grief!
Benign and gracious GEORGE, whoſe every deed
Throughout his holy life was amiable,
Diſpenſing bleſſings ever o'er his realms,
The ſtream of reaſon, and the ſpring of ſenſe,
As thou ſtill ſendeſt kindly, genial warmth,
To looſe the bands of Winter in due time;
So may it pleaſe THEE ſhortly to reſtore
To reaſon, health, and happineſs, OUR KING!

list.item: John Hobbs, the Tanner of Tamworth.

lg.l: YOU lately read in each news-paper,
At morn, at noon, by evening-taper,
Of Cheltenham-water, wooden-houſe,
Now left to prowling rat or mouſe;
With ſmart bon-mots, and anecdotes
Of Prince and Peaſant, Crowns and Cotes;
And how, ſurpriſed, the ruſtics ran
To ſee the King was but a man;
Wond'ring that blue-coat and bob-wig
Were worn by one they thought ſo big,
Great Gog or Magog's coat of mail
To cover him would ſurely fail:
How ſtars and garters clowns did ſcare,
And make them at a diſtance ſtare;
With Mayors, moſt loyally addreſſing,
To beg of Majeſty the bleſſing
Of one ſhort viſit to their city,
Which they, no doubt, had trimm'd up pretty:
With This anomalous expreſſion is not without a precedent; Man Mid-Wife, ſo generally uſed, being authority for it. female bell-man, ſqueaking out
"God ſave the King!" while ruſtics ſhout;
And gracious GEORGE, by chance being nigh her,
Moſt courteous adds, "God bleſs the cryer!"
Theſe, and a thouſand ſuch-like matters,
By news-papers now worn to tatters,
May prove a theme for ſome Stage-Writer,
Some Laureat-Bard, or Song-Enditer.
Tho' choice the ſubject, yet, thro' fear
We might debaſe it, were it here
Attempted to be dramatized,
It being ſo far overſized
For our weak talents; we, inſtead,
Evoke the Spirits of the Dead!
And crave you to accept a Story
Of our Fourth EDWARD, England's glory!
And a blunt Tanner; long ſince writ
By Thomas Heywood, a Stage-Wit:
Antique the phraſe, and coarſe the manners,
Yet ſuch as ſuited Kings and Tanners
Who lived three hundred years ago,
When few could to a gooſe ſay Bo!
And needy Kings would beg or borrow
What their poor ſubjects' toil and ſorrow
Had ſcraped together: happier now!
We under no ſuch bondage bow;
Nor King demands, nor ſubjects grieve,
Beneath our vines content we live!
And read with wonder of thoſe times,
The ſimple theme of this night's Mimes.
If it afford ſome harmleſs mirth,
Nor ſhew of humour quite a dearth;
Kindly o'erlook whate'er's amiſs,
Nor pay our labours with a hiſs:
And ſhould it pleaſe you to commend,
We ſhall atchieve our wiſh'd-for end;
For every thought, deed, and endeavour,
Is bent to gain that Prize, your Favour!

div.head: SCENE A Foreſt.

sp.speaker: HOBBS.
sp.p: DUDGEON, doſt thou hear? look well to Brock, my mare, drive Dun and her fair and ſoftly down the hill, and take heed the thorns tear not my cow-hides, as thou goeſt near the hedges.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.p: Maſter, the bull's hide is down.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Ha! what ſay'ſt thou knave? is the bull's hide down? why then hoiſt it up again. I'll meet thee at the ſtile, and help to ſet all ſtrait. [Exit Dudgeon.] And yet, heaven help us, it is a crooked world, and an unthrifty; for ſome that have ne'er a ſhoe had rather go barefoot, than buy clout-leather to mend the old, when they can get no new; well, heaven mend them, tho' they will not mend their ſhoes. Let me ſee by my executor here, my leather pouch, what I have taken, what I have ſpent, what I have gained, what I have loſt, and what I have laid out: My taking is more than my ſpending, for here's ſtore left. I have ſpent but a groat, a penny for my two jades, a penny to the poor, a penny pot of ale, and a penny cake, for my man and me.—A dicker of cow-hides coſt me —'ſnails, who comes here? Dame Ploughſhare, or Miſtreſs what d'ye call her? put up, John Hobbs, money tempts beauty.

div.stage: Enter the Queen and Dutcheſs, in riding dreſſes, and Two Huntſmen, with bows, &c.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Well met, good fellow, ſaw'ſt thou not the hart?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: My heart? heaven bleſs me from ſeeing my heart?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Thy heart? the deer, man, we demand the deer.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Do you demand what's dear? marry, corn and cow-hides.—Maſs! a good ſmug laſs. Well like my daughter Nell.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Cameſt thou not down the wood?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Yes, miſtreſs, that I did.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: And ſaw'ſt thou not the deer imboſt?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: By the rood ye make me laugh, ha! ha! ha! what the dickens is it, love! that makes ye prate to me ſo fondly?

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Huntſ.
sp.p: Why how now, Hobbs, ſo ſaucy with the Dutcheſs and the Queen?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: *Much Dutcheſs, and much Queen, I trow! theſe be but women; and one of them is as like my wench as a raw hide is to one that's not tann'd: I would Nell had her cloaths, I would give a load of hair and horns, and a fat of leather, to match her to ſome Juſtice, by the meg-holly.

sp.speaker: 2nd. Huntſ.
sp.p: Be ſilent, Tanner, and aſk pardon of the Queen.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: And ye be the Queen, I cry ye mercy, good Miſtreſs Queen!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Madam, let's take our bows, and in the ſtanding ſeek to get a ſhoot.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Come bend our bows, and bring the herd of deer.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Heaven ſend you good ſtriking, and fat fleſh.— See if all women, high or low, be not alike. I took the Queen for Dame Ploughſhare, as I am a true Tanner.

div.stage: Enter Sellenger and Howard in hunting dreſſes.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Soft, who comes here? more knaves yet!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Ho! good-fellow! ſaw'ſt thou not the king?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: No, good-fellow! I ſaw no King.—Which King doſt thou aſk for?

div.note: Much] Ben Jonſon uſes this word in the ſame ironical manner, "much wench, or much ſon!—Whalley's Edition, Vol. I. P. 102.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Why, King Edward, what King is there elſe?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: There's another King, and ye could hit on him; one Harry, one Harry! and by our Lady they ſay he's the honeſter man of the two.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Sirrah, beware you ſpeak not treaſon.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: What if I do?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Then you'll be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: That's a dog's death, I'll not meddle with it. But by my troth I know not when I do ſpeak treaſon, and when I don't; there's ſuch halting betwixt two Kings, that a man cannot go upright but he ſhall offend one of them: I would heaven had them both for me.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Well, thou ſaw'ſt not the King?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: No; is he in the Country?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p:
He's hunting here at Drayton-Baſſet.
Mr. Urban, I ſhould be obliged to any of your topographical friends, to inform me, why ſo many towns in North Wiltſhire have the addition of Baſſet to their names, as Wotton Baſſet, Compton Baſſet, Berwick Baſſet, &c. &c.? Every ſingularity of the kind ſhould be traced to its ſource; as it frequently produces exemplifications of ancient cuſtoms, or leads imperceptibly to diſcuſſions of antiquity, that ſeldom fail of rewarding us with ſome knowledge, that was before loſt to all but the incurious tenant of the ſoil. H. Gentleman's Magazine, 1788, Part 2, Page 885.
The ſeveral towns in North Wiltſhire which have the addition of Baſſet to their names, derive it from their owner Philip Baſſet, who had conſiderable property in the county, and was a younger branch of the Baſſets of Edendon there. See Dugdale's Bar. l. 383, 385. P.P. Idem, P. 973.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: The devil he is, God bleſs his maſterſhip! I ſaw a woman here, that they ſaid was the Queen. She's as like my daughter Nell as ever I ſee, but that my daughter's fairer.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Farewell, fellow; ſpeak well of the King.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p:
God make him an honeſt man, I hope that's well ſpoken; for, by the mouſe-foot, ſome give him hard words; whether he 'zerves um or not, let him look to that; I'll meddle o'my cow-hides, and let the world wag.
[Enter the King in a riding dreſs.] The devil in a dung-cart! how theſe royſters ſwarm in the country now the King is ſo near. 'deliver
me from this, for he looks more like a thief than a horſe! but a man cannot tell amongſt theſe court-nols who's true.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Now I have let my mother and the Queen, and all our train go by, let me awhile forget my Majeſty; and, 'ſtead of royal Edward, as the King's attendant have ſome ſport with yonder ruſtic. Hollo! my friend! good-fellow, prithee ſtay.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: No ſuch matter. I am in haſte.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: If thou be a good-fellow, let me borrow a word.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: My purſe thou mean'ſt.—I am no good-fellow, and I pray heaven thou beeſt not one.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why, doſt thou not love a good-fellow.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: No; 'tis a bye-word, good-fellows be thieves.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Doſt thou think I am one?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Thought is free, and thou art not my ghoſtly father

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: In faith, I mean thee no harm.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Who knoweth that but thyſelf?—I pray heaven he ſpied not my purſe!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: On my troth I mean thee none.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Well, upon thy oath I'll ſtay.—Now what ſay'ſt thou to me? ſpeak quickly, for my company ſtays for me beneath at the next ſtile.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The King is hunting hereabouts; did'ſt thou ſee his Majeſty?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: His Majeſty? what's that? his horſe or his mare?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Tuſh, I mean his Grace.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Grace, quotha! pray heaven he have any.—Which King doth thou 'quire for?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why, for King Edward.—Know'ſt thou any more Kings than one?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: I know not ſo many, for I tell thee I know none.— Marry, I hear of King Edward.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Did'ſt thou ſee his highneſs?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Now, by my holydame, that's the beſt term thou gaveſt him yet; he's high enough, but he has put poor King Harry low enough.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How low hath he put him?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Nay I cannot tell, but he has got the Crown from him, much good do him with it!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Amen! I like thy talk ſo well, I would I knew thy name.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Doſt thou not know me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Then thou know'ſt nobody; did'ſt never hear of John Hobbs, the Tanner of Tamworth?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Not till now, I promiſe thee; but now I do know thee, I like thee well.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: So do not I thee.—I doubt thou art ſome out-rider, that lives by taking of purſes, here on Baſſet-heath.—But I fear thee not; for I have wared all my money in cowhides, at Coleſill market; and my man and my mare are hard by at the hill-foot.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Is that thy grey mare, that's tied at the ſtile, with the hides on her back?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Ay, that's Brock, my mare; and there's Dun, my nag; and Dudgeon, my man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There's neither man, nor horſe; but only the mare.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Od's blue bodkin! has the knave ſerved me ſo? farewell. I may loſe hides, horns, mare, and all, by prating with thee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Tarry, man, tarry! they'll ſooner take my bay gelding, than thy grey mare; for I have tied mine by her.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: That will I ſee before I take your word.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I'll bear thee company.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: If you will, you muſt; but I had much rather go alone.

div.head: The SCENE continues.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Huntſ.
sp.p: Now, by my troth, the Queen ſhoots paſſing well.

sp.speaker: 2nd. Huntſ.
sp.p: So did the Dutcheſs, when ſhe was as young.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Huntſ.
sp.p: Age ſhakes the hand, and ſhoots both wide and ſhort.

sp.speaker: 2nd. Huntſ.
sp.p: What have they given us?

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Huntſ.
sp.p: Six roſe-nobles juſt.

sp.speaker: 2nd. Huntſ.
sp.p: The Queen gave four.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Huntſ.
sp.p: Right, and the Dutcheſs two; had the King come, he would have rained on us ſhowers of gold.

sp.speaker: 2nd. Huntſ.
sp.p: Why, he is hunting, ſomewhere hereabout.— Let us firſt drink the Queen and Dutcheſs' health, and then go ſeek him.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Huntſ.
sp.p: Agreed.

div.stage: Another part of the Foreſt, at the bottom of the hill.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How ſay'ſt thou, Tanner? wilt thou take my courſer for thy mare?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Courſer, call'ſt thou him? he's too fine for me! thy ſkittiſh jade will neither carry my leather, horns, nor hides. But if I were ſo mad to change, what would'ſt thou give me to boot?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay, boot that's boot-worthy —I look for boot of thee.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! that's a merry jig! why, man, Brock, my mare, knows ha and ree; will ſtand when I cry ho, let me get up when I ſay hi, and down when I ſay hee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well, I'll give thee a noble if I like her pace; lay thy cow-hides on my ſaddle, and let's jog towards Drayton.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: 'Tis out of my way; but I begin to like thee well.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thou wilt like me better ere we part.—I pray thee tell me, what ſay they of the King?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Of the Kings, thou mean'ſt.—Art thou no blab if I do tell thee?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: If the King knows not now, he ſhall never know it for me.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Maſs, they ſay King Harry's a very advowtry man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: A devout man; and what's King Edward?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: He's a frank franion, a merry companion, and loves a wench well; they ſay he has married a poor widow becauſe ſhe is fair.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Doſt thou like him the worſe for that?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: No, by my feckens, but the better; for though I be but a plain Tanner, I love a fair laſs myſelf.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Prithee, tell me, how love they King Edward?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Faith, as poor folks love holidays.—Glad to have them now and then, but to have them come too often would undo them; ſo to ſee the King now and then is a comfort, but to behold him every day would beggar us; and I may ſay to thee, under the roſe, we fear we ſhall be troubled to lend him money, for we doubt he's but needy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Would'ſt thou not lend him money if he ſhould need it?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Yes, by my holydame! he ſhall have half my purſe, and I'll ſell ſole-leather to help him to more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: In faith now, which lov'ſt thou beſt, Harry or Edward?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Nay, that's a ſecret! and two may keep it, if one be away.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Shall I ſay my conſcience? I think Harry is the true King.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Art adviſed of that? Harry's of the old houſe of Lancaſter, and that progenity do I love.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Then doſt thou hate the Houſe of York?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Why, no; for I am juſt a-kin to Sutton wind-mill; I can grind which way ſoe'er the wind blow: If it be Harry, I can ſay well fare Lancaſter! if it be Edward, I can ſing, York, York for my money!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thou art of my mind, for I ſay Harry is the lawful King; Edward is but a uſurper; fool and a coward.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Nay, there thou lyeſt! he has wit enough, and courage enough; doſt thou not ſpeak treaſon?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ay; but I know to whom I ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Doſt thou? an I were conſtable, I ſhould be forſworn if I ſet thee not in the ſtocks for it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well, let it go no further; for I did ſerve King Harry, and I love him beſt; though now I ſerve King Edward.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Thou art the arranter knave to ſpeak ill of thy maſter. But, ſirrah, what's thy name? what office haſt thou? and what will the King do for thee?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My name is Ned; I am the King's butler, and he will do more for me than for any nobleman in the court.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: The devil he will! the more fool he, and ſo I'll tell him if e'er I ſee him; and I would I might ſee him in my poor houſe at Tamworth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Go with me to the court, and I'll bring thee to the King; and what ſuit ſoever thou have to him, I'll warrant thee to ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: I ha' nothing to do at court; I'll home with my cow-hides; but if the King will come to me, he ſhall be welcome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Haſt thou no ſuit touching thy trade? to tranſport hides, or have the ſole ſelling of leather within a certain circuit; or about bark, or ſuch like, to have letters patent.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: By the maſs, I like not thoſe patents! for, I think it's pity that only one ſubject ſhould have, what might do good to many throughout the land.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou me ſo, Tanner? well, let's caſt lots, whether thou ſhalt go with me to Drayton, or I go home with thee to Tamworth.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Lot me no lotting! I'll not go with thee; if thou wilt go with me, 'cauſe thou'rt my Liege's man (and yet I think he has many honeſter) thou ſhalt be welcome to John Hobbs: thou ſhalt be welcome to beef and bacon; and perhaps a bag-pudding: and my daughter Nell ſhall make a poſſet for thee ere thou goeſt to bed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Here's my hand.—I'll but go and ſee the King ſerved, and be at home as ſoon as thyſelf; ay, and, with thy leave and her's, kiſs thy fair daughter too.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.l: That's hereafter as it may be; but,
Doſt thou hear me Ned? if I ſhall be thy hoſt,
Make haſte, thou wert beſt, for fear thou kiſs the poſt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Farewell, John Hobbs, the honeſt true Tanner!—
I ſee plain men, by obſervation
Of things that alter in the change of times,
Do gather knowledge; and the meaneſt life,
Portion'd with but content's ſufficiency,
Is happier than the mighty ſtate of Kings.
How now? what news bring ye, Sirs?
Where's the Queen?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Her highneſs and your mother, my dread Lord,
Are both invited by Sir Humphrey Bowes,
Where they intend to feaſt and lodge to night,
And do expect your Grace's preſence there.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tom Sellenger, I have other buſineſs.
Aſtray from you and all my other train,
I met a Tanner; ſuch a merry mate,
So frolick, and ſo full of good conceit,
That I have given my word to be his gueſt;
Becauſe he knows me not to be the King:
Good couſin Howard grudge not at the jeſt,
But greet my mother and my wife for me;
Bid them be merry; I muſt have my humour;
Let them both ſup and ſleep when they ſee time;
Commend me kindly to Sir Humphrey Bowes,
Tell him at breakfaſt I will viſit him.
This night Tom Sellenger and I muſt feaſt
With Hobbs, the Tanner; there plain Ned and Tom,
The King and Sellenger awhile forgot.

div.stage: Enter a Meſſenger, booted, with letters, and kneeling gives them to the King.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: The Queen and Dutcheſs will be diſcontent,
Becauſe his Highneſs comes not to the feaſt.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir Humphrey Bowes may take the moſt offence;
But there's no help; the King will have his pleaſure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Good news, my boys; Harry the ſixth is dead.
Peruſe this letter. Sirrah, drink you that,
And ſtay not, but poſt back again for life,
And thank my brother Gloſter for his news;
Commend me to him; I'll ſee him tomorrow night.
How like ye it, Sirs?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: O, paſſing well, my Liege;
You may be merry for this happy news.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The merrier with our hoſt, the Tanner, Tom;
My Lord, take you that letter to the ladies;
Bid them be merry as good news can make them:
And if we ſee them not before we go,
Pray them to journey eaſily after us.
We'll poſt to London, ſo good night, my Lord.
And now ſet forward on thy frolick, Ned!
Come, Tom; the word's Fat Bacon and Brown Bread!

div.head: SCENE, Hobbs's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Hobbs, and his daughter Nell.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Come, Nell, come daughter, be your hands and face waſhed?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Ay, forſooth, father.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Ye muſt be cleanly I can tell ye, for there comes a court-nol hither to-night, the King's maſterſhip's butler, Ned; a ſpruce youth; but beware ye be not in love, nor overtaken by him, for Courtiers be ſlippery lads.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: No, forſooth, father.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: God's bleſſing on thee! that half-year's ſchooling at Liechfield, was better to thee than houſe and land, it has put ſuch manners into thee: Ay, forſooth; and no forſooth, at every word. Is ſupper ready?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Ay, forſooth, father.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Have we a good barley bag-pudding, a piece of fat bacon, a good cow-heel, a hard cheeſe, and a brown loaf?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: All this, forſooth; and more, ye ſhall have a poſſet: but, indeed, the rats have ſpoiled your hard cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Now, the devil choak them! for they eat me a whole candle the other night.

sp.speaker: Dudgeon.
sp.p: (within) What, Maſter! Maſter!

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: How, now, Knave? what ſay'ſt thou, Dudgeon?

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.p: Here's gueſts come. Where's Ellen?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: What gueſts be they?

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.p: A court-nol; one Ned, the King's butcher, he ſays; and his friend too.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Ned, the King's butcher? ha, ha, ha!—the King's butler, thou mean'ſt; take their horſes, and walk them, and bid them come in doors. [Exit Dudgeon.] Nell, lay the cloth, and ſupper o'th' board.

div.l: Maſs! here's Ned, indeed; and another miſproud ruffian.—
Welcome Ned! I like thy honeſty, thou keep'ſt promiſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I'faith, honeſt Tanner, I'll ever keep promiſe with thee:—prithee, bid my friend welcome.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: By my troth ye are both welcome to Tamworth! friend, I know not your name.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: My name is Tom Twiſt.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Tom Twiſt? belike then you are the King's taylor.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: No, faith.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Ye are welcome both; and I like you well, but for one thing.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Nay, that I keep to myſelf.—For I grieve to think that pride brings many to extruction.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Prithee, tell us thy meaning.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Troth, I doubt ye ne'er came truly by all theſe gay trappings. 'Tis not your bare wages, and thin fees ye have of the King, can keep ye thus fine; but either ye muſt rob the King privily, or his ſubjects openly, to maintain your prodigality.—But, come, let's to ſupper.—What, Nell! what, Dudgeon!—where be theſe folks?

div.stage: Enter Nell and Dudgeon, with a table covered.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Ye are welcome, gentlemen, as I may ſay, forſooth.
sp.stage: The King and Sellenger kiſs her.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I thank ye, fair maid.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: A pretty wench, faith!

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: How lik'ſt her, Ned?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I like her ſo well, I would ye would make me your ſon-in-law.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: And I like thee ſo well, Ned; that, had'ſt thou an occupation, (for ſervice is no heritage, and a young courtier, an old beggar.) I could find in my heart to caſt her away upon thee; and, if thou wilt forſake the court, and turn Tanner, here with me at Tamworth, or bind thyſelf to a Shoe-maker, in Liechfield, I'll give thee twenty nobles, ready money, with my Nell; and truſt thee with a dicker of leather to ſet up thy trade.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Ned, he offers ye fair, if ye have the grace to take it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: He does, indeed Tom; and hereafter I'll tell him more.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Come, ſit down to ſupper. [They ſit.] Go to, Nell! no more ſheep's eyes; ye may be caught, I tell you; theſe be licoriſh lads.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I warrant ye, father. Yet, in truth, Ned is a very proper man; and to'ther may ſerve, but Ned's a pearl in mine eye.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p:
Daughter, call Dudgeon and his fellows, we'll have a three-man-ſong, to make our gueſts merry.
Exit Nell. 'Nails! what court-nols are ve? ye'll neither eat nor talk. What news at the court? do ſomewhat for your meat.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Heavy news there. King Henry is dead.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: That's light news and merry for your maſter, King Edward.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But how will the commons take it?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p:
Troth, the commons will take it as a common thing, and ſay, Well! God be with good King Henry! death's an honeſt man, for he ſpares not the King.—
As one comes, another's ta'en away,
And ſeldom comes a better, as a body may ſay.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Shrewdly ſpoken, Tanner, by my faith.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Come, fill me a cup of mother Whetſtone's ale, that I may drink to my friends; Here's to ye, Ned and Tom, with all my heart! [drinks] and yet, I doubt, if I come to the court, you'll not know me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Yes, faith! Tom ſhall be my ſurety, Tanner, I will know thee.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: If thou doſt not, Ned, thou deſerv'ſt that the King ſhould not know thee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Come, honeſt Tanner, I drink to thy fair daughter, Nell; my wife that may be.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: • faith Ned, thou may'ſt live to make her a lady.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Tuſh, her father offers nothing, having no more children but her.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: I would I had not, condition ſhe had all; but I have a knave to my ſon, juſt ſuch an unthrift as one of you two; that ſpends all on gay cloaths and new faſhions, and no work will go down with him, that I fear he'll be hang'd; heaven bleſs you to a better fate! tho', by my troth, I doubt it; but come, let's drive away care with a good old ſong.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Well ſung good fellows, I would the King heard you.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: So would I; i'faith, I ſhould ſtrain a note for him. Come, take away, and let's to bed—ye ſhall have clean ſheets, Ned, tho' they be coarſe; good ſtrong hemp, of my daughter's own ſpinning.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thanks, honeſt Hobbs! but we'll not go to bed.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: What then? let's ha' more ale.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No more, good friend; we'll mount our horſes, and with ſpeed to London, for it is near day; and, honeſt Tanner! gramercy for our hearty cheer. If e'er it be thy chance to come to court, enquire for me, Ned, the King's Butler; or Tom, of the King's Chamber, my companion, and ſee what welcome we will give the there.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: I have heard of courtiers have ſaid as much as you, and when they have been tried, would not ſo much as aſk their friends to drink.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: We are none ſuch, believe me, honeſt Tanner. So now to horſe, for we muſt ſtrait away; and ſo, with hearty thanks, friend Hobbs, farewell.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.

div.head: SCENE, An Antique Hall.
div.stage: Sir Humphrey Bowes and Juſtice Aſton, ſeated.

sp.speaker: SIR HUMPHREY BOWES.
sp.l: NEighbours and friends, the cauſe why you are call'd
Concerns the King's moſt excellent majeſty,
Whoſe right, you know, by his progenitors,
Unto the crown and ſovereignty of France,
Is wrongfully detained by the French.
Which to revenge and royally regain,
His highneſs means to put himſelf in arms,
And in his princely perſon to conduct
His warlike troops againſt the enemy.
But, for his coffers are unfurniſhed,
Through civil diſcord and inteſtine war,
For York and Lancaſter's diſputed claim,
(Whoſe bleeding ſcars our eyes may yet behold)
He prays his faithful, loving ſubjects' help
To further this his juſt great enterpriſe.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: So, the drift and meaning, whereby as it were, of all your long purgation, Sir Humphrey Bowes, is no more in ſome reſpect, but that the King wants money, and would ha' ſome of his commonality.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Tanner, you rightly underſtand the matter.

sp.speaker: J. Aſton.
sp.l: Note this withall; where his dread majeſty,
(Our lawful ſovereign, and moſt royal King)
Might have exacted or impoſed a tax,
Or borrow'd greater ſums than we can ſpare,
(For all we have is at his dread command)
He doth not ſo; but mildly doth intreat
Our kind benevolence, what we will give,
With willing minds towards this mighty charge.
Which to receive, his noble counſellor,
And kinſman, the Lord Howard here is come.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: Now good Sir Humphrey Bowes, and Juſtice Aſton,
Have ye declared the King's moſt gracious pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: We have, my lord.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: His highneſs will not force,
As loan or tribute; but will take your gift
In grateful part, and recompence your loves.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.l: To ſhew my love, though money now be ſcarce,
A hundred pounds I'll give his majeſty.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: 'Tis well, Sir Humphrey!

sp.speaker: J. Aſton.
sp.p: I a hundred marks.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: Thanks, Juſtice Aſton! you both ſhew your love.
Now aſk your neighbours what they will beſtow?

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Come, maſter Hadland, your benevolence.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.l: O, good Sir Humphrey. do not rack my purſe.
You know my ſtate, I lately ſold my land.

sp.speaker: J Aſton.
sp.p: Then you have money; let the King have part.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Ay, do, maſter Hadland, do; they ſay ye ſold a foul deal of dirty land for fair gold and ſilver; let the King have ſome, now, while ye have it; if ye be forborne a while, all will be ſpent: for he who cannot keep land, that lies faſt, will have much ado to hold money: 'tis ſlippery ware! 'tis melting ware!

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Gramercy, Tanner!

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Say, what ſhall we have?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: My forty ſhillings.

sp.speaker: J. Aſton.
sp.l: Robert Goodfellow,
I know you will be liberal to the King.

sp.speaker: Goodf.
sp.l: O, Juſtice Aſton, be content I pray ye;
You know my charge, my houſehold very great,
And my houſe-keeping holds me very bare;
Threeſcore up-riſing and down-lying, Sir,
Spend no ſmall ſtore of victuals in a year;
Two brace of greyhounds, twenty couple of hounds;
And then my horſes eat a deal of corn;
My chriſtmas coſt, and friends that then do come,
Amounts to charge; I am Robin Good fellow,
That welcome all, and keep a frolick houſe;
But have no money,—pray ye pardon me.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Why hear you, goodman Goodfellow! (tho' you are much miſcall'd) hear a plain Tanner, who will teach you thrift; Keep fewer dogs and horſes, and then you may feed more men; yet feed no idle men, 'tis needleſs charge: but ſurely you, that for hounds and hunting mates do ſpare for nought, will ſomething ſpare unto your king.

sp.speaker: Goodf.
sp.p: My brace of angels, by my troth that's all.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Maſs! and 'tis well the curs have left ſo much; I thought they would have eaten up thy land ere this.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Now, Harry Grudgen.

sp.speaker: Grud.
sp.p: What would you have of me? money I have none, and I'll ſell no ſtock; here's old polling!—ſubſidy, ſoldiers, and to the poor! and you might have your will, you'd ſoon ſhut me out of doors.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Now, by my holydame, neighbour Grudgen, thou'rt but a grumbling, grudging churl! thou haſt two ploughs going, and ne'er a cradle rocking, with many a peck of money; and wilt not ſpare a few pounds to the King.

sp.speaker: Grud.
sp.p: Marry come up, goodman Tanner, are you ſo tart? your prolicateneſs has brought your ſon to the gallows almoſt; you can be frank of another man's coſt.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Thou'rt no good man to twit me with my ſon; he may outlive thee yet: my ſon's in jail;—is he the firſt honeſt man's ſon that hath been there? and thou wert a man as thou'rt but a beaſt, I would have thee by the ears.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: Friend, thou want'ſt nurture to upbraid a father
With a ſon's fault; we ſit not here for this.
What's thy benevolence to his Majeſty?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: His beneligence? hang him! he'll not give a penny willingly.

sp.speaker: Grud.
sp.p: I care not much to caſt away forty pence.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: Out, grudging peaſant! baſe, ill-nurtur'd groom!
Is this the love thou bear'ſt unto the King?
Gentlemen, take notice of the ſlave,
And if he fault let him be ſoundly plagued.
Now, frolick Tanner, what wilt thou afford?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Twenty old angels, and a ſcore of hides; if that be too little, take twenty nobles more: while I have it my King ſhall never want.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: The King ſhall know thy loving, liberal heart.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Shall he, i faith? I thank ye heartily! but, hear ye, gentlemen, come ye from the court?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Lord, how does the King? and how does Ned, the King's butler? and Tom of his chamber? I am ſure ye know them.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I do, and they are well,

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: For want of better gueſts they were at my houſe one night.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I know they were.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: They promiſed me a good turn for kiſſing my daughter, Nell; and now I ha' cagion to try them; my ſon's in Caperdochia, as they call it, in Newgate jail; for peeping into another man's purſe: and outcept the King be miſerable, he's like to totter for lack of ground to ſtand on! can that ſame Ned, the butler, do any thing with the King?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: More than myſelf or any other Lord.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: A halter he can! by my troth ye rejoice my heart to hear it.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Come to the court; I warrant thy ſon's life; Ned will ſave that, and do thee greater good.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.l: Then fare ye well, Sirs!
I'll wean my mare's foal, and come up to the King;
And you for your pains, two fat hens will I bring.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And have our country ſubjects been ſo frank,
And bountiful in their benevolence,
Toward our preſent expedition?
Thanks, couſin Howard, for thy pains herein:
We will have letters ſent to every ſhire,
Of thankful gratitude, that they may know
How highly we reſpect their gentleneſs.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: One thing, my lord, I had well nigh forgot;
Your pleaſant hoſt, the Tanner of Tamworth—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What of him, coufin?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: He was right liberal;
Twenty old angels and as many nobles,
With a ſcore hides, he gave unto your grace;
And others, ſeeing him ſo bountiful,
Stretch'd further than they otherwiſe had done.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Truſt me I muſt requite that honeſt Tanner.
O, had he kept his word, and come to court,
In faith we ſhould have had good ſtore of mirth.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: That is not long, my lord, which haps at laſt;
He's come to London on an earneſt cauſe.
His ſon lies priſoner in Newgate-jail,
And is condemned for a robbery.
Your higneſs pardoning his ſon's default,
May yield the Tanner no mean recompence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But who hath ſeen him ſince he came to town?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My lord, in Holborn 'twas my hap to ſee him
Gazing about; I ſent away my men,
And, clapping on one of their livery cloaks,
Accoſted him; the Tanner knew me ſtrait;
How now, Tom? and how doth Ned? quoth he,
That honeſt, merry hangman, how doth he?
I, knowing that your majeſty intended
This day in perſon to come to the Tower,
There bade him meet me, where mad Ned and I
Would bring him to the preſence of the King,
And there procure a pardon for his ſon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Have then a care we be not ſeen of him,
Until we be provided for the purpoſe;
Becauſe once more we'll have a little ſport.
Tom Sellenger, let that care be your's.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I warrant you, my lord; I will not fail.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Welcome, Lord Mayor! Recorder, Sheriffs, all!
Say, worthy friends, have you well ſignified
Our thankfulneſs unto our citizens,
For their late gathered benevolence?

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.l: So, pleaſe your highneſs it has juſt been done;
Before the citizens in our guild-hall,
Maſter Recorder made a long oration
Of thankful gratitude for their kind gifts;
Which they received with ſo great reſpect,
And love unto your royal majeſty,
As it appear'd to us they ſorrowed
Their bounty to your highneſs was no more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lord Mayor, and Sirs, thanks to yourſelves and them
And go ye with us now unto the Tower,
To ſee the order that we ſhall obſerve
In this ſo needful warlike preparation,
To gain our lawful right from haughty France;
The better may ye certifie to them,
What need there was of their benevolence.
And, gentle Sheriffs, as we paſs along,
A word in private about other matters.
While we to quell our foes abroad to roam,
Let's not forget our ſubjects' bliſs at home!

div.head: SCENE, The Tower.
div.stage: Enter King, Lord Mayor, Recorder, Howard, Sellenger, and the train.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Having awak'd forth of their ſleepy dens
Our drowſy cannon, which ere long ſhall charm
The watchful French, with Death's eternal ſleep,
And all things elſe in readineſs for France,
A while we will give truce unto our care.
There is a merry Tanner near at hand,
With whom we mean to have a little mirth;
Therefore, Lord Mayor, and you my other friends,
I muſt intreat you not to knowledge me;
No man ſtand bare, but as companions all:
So, Tanner, now come when you pleaſe;—and ſee
Where, in good time, he comes. Go, Tom, and meet him.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: What, John Hobbs? welcome i'faith, to court.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Gramercy, honeſt Tom! where is the hangman Ned? where is that mad raſcal? ſhall I not ſee him?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: See, there he ſtands; that ſame is he.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: What, Ned! a plague on thee, how doſt thou for a mad rogue? and how, and how?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: In health, John Hobbs, and very glad to ſee thee; But ſay, what wind drove thee to London?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Ah. Ned! I was brought hither with a whirlwind, man; my ſon! my ſon! did I not tell thee I had a knave to my ſon?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Yes, Tanner, what of him?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Faith, he's in Caperdochia, Ned; in Newgate-goal, for a robbery: and is like to be hang'd, outcept thou get the King to be more miſerable to him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If that be all, Tanner, I'll warrant him;
I will procure his pardon of the King.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p:
Wilt thou, Ned? for thoſe good words, ſee what my daughter Nell hath ſent thee; a hankercher wrought with as good Coventry-blue
"And ſhe gave me a ſhirt-collar, wrought over
With no counterfeit ſtuff.
What, was it gold?
Nay, 'twas better than gold.
What was it?
Right Coventry blue."
George A Greene, The Pinner of Wakefield, 1599.
By this paſſage Coventry-blue appears to have been formerly held in great eſtimation. ſilk thread as ever thou ſaw'ſt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And I, perhaps, may wear it for her ſake,
In better preſence than thou art aware of.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: How, Ned; a better preſent? that can'ſt thou not have, for ſilk, cloth, and workmanſhip; why Nell made it, man!—But, Ned, is not the King in this company? what's he in the white beard and red petticoat? By the maſs, I miſdoubt, Ned, that is the King: I know it by my Lord What-ye-call-um's players.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How by them, Tanner?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Why, ever when they play an Enterlout, or a Commodity, at Tamworth, the King is always in a white-beard, and a red-gown like him; therefore I 'ſpect him to be the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No, truſt me, Tanner, that is not the King; but thou ſhalt ſee the King before thou goeſt, and have a pardon for thy ſon with thee.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Then what is he i'th'red-gown, and he i'th'black?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: That is the Mayor, Lord-Mayor of London; the other is the Recorder.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: What nick-names theſe Court-nols have for one-another! Mare and Corder, quotha!—We have no ſuch at Tamworth or Liechfield; there is the honeſt bailiff and his brethren: ſuch words 'gree beſt with us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My Lord-Mayor, and good Mr. Recorder, I pray ye, for my ſake, to bid this honeſt Tanner welcome.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.l: You are welcome, my honeſt friend!
In ſign whereof, I pray you ſee my houſe,
And ſup with me this night.

sp.speaker: Record.
sp.p: And, if it pleaſe you, dine with me tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: I thank ye, goodman Mare! and Maſter Corder! but I care not for no meat; my ſtomach is like to a ſick ſwine's, that will neither eat nor drink, 'till ſhe know what will become of her pig.—Ned and Tom, ye promiſed me a good turn when I came to Court; either do it now, and ſave my ſon from the gallows, or go hang yourſelves.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No ſooner comes the King, but I will do it.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I warrant thee, Tanner; fear not thy ſon's life.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Nay, I fear not his life; 'tis his death I fear.

div.stage: Enter the Sheriffs and Young Hobbs.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Sher.
sp.p: All health and happineſs attend my ſovereign!

sp.speaker: 2d. Sher.
sp.p: Here is the young man, Hobbs, condemn'd to die.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Sovereign! and my ſon! O that ever I was born!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Look to the Tanner! chafe his temples, Sirs!
This unlook'd meeting and diſcovery
Have overpower'd his faculties.

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.l: Let me alone,—I'm a dead man!—
Ah, my liege! that ye ſhould deal ſo with a poor ſimple
Tanner! but its no matter, I can but die.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But when, Tanner? can'ſt thou tell?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Nay, e'en when ye pleaſe; for I have ſo defended ye, by calling ye plain Ned, mad rogue, and raſcal, that I know ye'll have me hang'd. Therefore, no more ado, but let my ſon and I e'en be truſs'd up together.—And here's another, as honeſt as yourſelf no doubt; ye made me call him plain Tom, and I warrant his name is Thomas, and ſome man of worſhip too; therefore, let's to our doom, e'en when and where ye will.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tanner, attend! not only do we pardon thee
Thy plain and blunt, tho' honeſt, well-meant ſpeech,
But in all princely kindneſs welcome thee!
And thy ſon's treſpaſs do we pardon too;
With this obſervance, that he ſin no more
In ſuch-like ſort, elſe ſhall he ſurely die!
For he who from his prince's clemency
Hath once received a juſtly-forfeit life,
And brings it into jeopardy again,
Deſerves not mercy, nor e'en pity merits.

sp.speaker: Y. Hobbs.
sp.l: If I offend again, my gracious liege!
Let me not mercy, nor e'en pity find.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis well! Receive with kindneſs thy repentant ſon;
And in return for what thou freely gav'ſt
To aid our enterpriſe 'gainſt haughty France,
We give to thee and thine in yearly fee
An hundred marks; now, Tanner, what doſt ſay?

sp.speaker: Hobbs.
sp.p: Why, an'like your kingſhip, I can ſcarce ſay at all! but, I thank ye!—I thank ye for my ſon's life, I thank ye for not putting me to death; and when I get back to Tamworth, my Nell ſhall work a ſcarf, and ſend ye; and I'll not forget a ſkin of choice cordovan, of my own tanning, to make ye boots againſt ye next go a hunting: when, if ye would but once more leave your kingſhip behind ye, come to my poor hovel, and be plain hail-fellow Ned again, we'd have ſuch a rowſe, as ſhould make all the hair on my hides ſtand an end! and ſo, farewell!
sp.l: Heaven bleſs ye! ſtill I'll ſay or ſing,
Long live your Majeſty! God ſave the King!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Drama ended, EDWARD is no more!
But for his loſs we little need deplore;
GEORGE, great and good! yet lives, and may he long!
Join, then, all loyal hearts in cheerful ſong;
Lift high your voices 'till the roof doth ring,
In duteous homage to great GEORGE our KING!

div.p: Song and Chorus of "GOD SAVE THE KING!"

list.item: Page 7, line 2, read from ſeeing my heart!
Page 9, near the bottom, read Which King doſt thou 'quire for?
Page 12, ibid. read a fool and a coward.
Page 17, line 18, read and t'other may ſerve.
Idem, line 24, read Heavy news there.
Page 18, near the bottom, read we will give thee there.

Idem, Divide the laſt ſpeech but one into verſe, e. g.
We, &c.
So now, &c
And ſo, &c.
The like may be neceſſary in ſome other places overlook'd.
Page 23, line 20, read Your highneſs pardoning, &c.
Page 24, line 22, read abroad do roam, &c.
Correct alſo you into ye, wherever it may occur in HOBBS's ſpeeches.
